discussion.content: The Security tech would put the tape up to stop anyone but the forensic team from approaching the ATM... The forensics team would then...

Should be D & B. Controlling the crime scene is important, then you initiate the Chain of Custody. This would be the full order of all items:

D. Crime tape
B. Chain of custody form
C. Write blockers
A. Drive adapters
F. Drive imager
E. Hashing utilities

comments.content: I wouldn't think so. Since there are multiple forensic examiners are involved in this investigation, Using Chain of Custody form from the scene would be their higher priority.

questions.question_text:
An ATM in a building lobby has been compromised. A security technician has been advised that the ATM must be forensically analyzed by multiple technicians.
Which of the following items in a forensic tool kit would likely be used FIRST? (Choose two.)

A business-critical application is unable to support the requirements in the current password policy because it does not allow the use of special characters.
Management does not want to accept the risk of a possible security incident due to weak password standards. Which of the following is an appropriate means to limit the risks related to the application?

discussion.content: I don't think encrypting the authenticating traffic will minimize the risk of weak passwords as it will still be vulnerable to brute force or other kinds of attack. I think this is A, in general.

I would choose B--altering password policy such that a password does not have to contain a special character, but it has to be, say 20 letters, in length. 

Note: The problem with 'A' is that it does not say which compensation tool will we use. It may or may not be effective to compensate weak authentication.
Should be A

This should be A

A compensating control, also called an alternative control, is a mechanism that is put in place to satisfy the requirement for a security measure that is deemed too difficult or impractical to implement at the present time.

Should be A. 
A compensating control.

I believe the answer should be A as compensation control using 2FA will make the application more resilient against brute force attacks. 

The question didn't state if the traffic was or not encrypted so D doesn't make much sense. Encrypting the traffic doesn't prevent bruteforcing the password.
what kind of compensating control? I think its D since it indicates a specific workaround

comments.content: Account Lockout as well is another compensating control.

discussion.content: Agreed, unencrypted passwords in general is a problem, whether complex or weak password is used. Encrypt the password “Passw0rd” and it is still prone the same attack. Brute force, etc. A is correct.
Agreed, a really dumb question with none of the answers being satisfactory

questions.question_text:
A threat intelligence analyst who works for a financial services firm received this report:
"There has been an effective waterhole campaign residing at www.bankfinancecompsoftware.com. This domain is delivering ransomware. This ransomware variant has been called "LockMaster" by researchers due to its ability to overwrite the MBR, but this term is not a malware signature. Please execute a defensive operation regarding this attack vector."
The analyst ran a query and has assessed that this traffic has been seen on the network. Which of the following actions should the analyst do NEXT? (Choose two.)

choices.C: Produce a threat intelligence message to be disseminated to the company
choices.E: Advise the security analysts to add an alert in the SIEM on the string "LockMaster"
choices.B: Visit the domain and begin a threat assessment
choices.F: Format the MBR as a precaution
choices.D: Advise the security architects to enable full-disk encryption to protect the MBR
choices.A: Advise the firewall engineer to implement a block on the domain

discussion.content: I think what we need to pay the most attention to is the word “NEXT”... ABD are all correct, but I believe A and D are first, to attempt to stop the threat. Once you have contained it the best you can, you then would begin an assessment on the domain.

Nobody thinks that C makes sense? Advising your staff that this is a known threat going around and to not entertain it as it is a ransomware. 
The expression full disk encryption (FDE) (or whole disk encryption) signifies that everything on the disk is encrypted, but the master boot record (MBR), or similar area of a bootable disk, with code that starts the operating system loading sequence, is not encrypted.
I believe the answer is: A and C.

This is a waterhole attack, website that the user uses is delivering malware, using A it will cause an outage.

B and D.

A & D should be the answer.
A. Advise the firewall engineer to implement a block on the domain
D. Advise the security architects to enable full-disk encryption to protect the MBR
__ __

Why would you visit the domain as first action? Doing that will get you infected and should be done after securing your environment.
I believe its this sentence that matters the most " Please execute a defensive operation regarding this attack vector." Therefore A and D are the answer.

comments.content: i believe encrypting the disk doesn't do much if the ransomware had gotten admin rights. it could easily change the permissions to allow infection

discussion.content: the answers make sense, as the ransomware is already on the system -- so encrypt the disk to stop it in its tracks and visit the domain to observe what it's likely to do

comments.content: so, A and B would be a better choice?

discussion.content:
I'm thinking it can either be A,B,D
A - since the domain is found to be malicious and source of ransomware variant, preventive measure is to block the domain so users can't access the site
- B - visiting the domain and begin threat assessment to be able to get more details and the behavior and how we can prevent this threat
D - enabling FDE to protect the MBR. But this one is tricky as not all FDE can protect the MBR. Some hardware-based FDE can protect the MBR.
If the domain is ransomware, why would you visit it?
program meets all required best practices ISO
ISO. D.

questions.question_text: The Chief Information Security Officer (CISO) has asked the security staff to identify a framework on which to base the security program. The CISO would like to achieve a certification showing the security program meets all required best practices. Which of the following would be the BEST choice?

A security analyst is concerned that employees may attempt to exfiltrate data prior to tendering their resignations. Unfortunately, the company cannot afford to purchase a data loss prevention system. Which of the following recommendations should the security analyst make to provide defense-in-depth against data loss?
(Choose three.)

discussion.content:
ABE are the correct answers.
__ __
C. Prevent users from copying data from workstation to workstation
- This could lead to admin overhead.
D. Prevent users from using roaming profiles when changing workstations
- Users might need to switch departments so preventing roaming profiles could cause admin overhead.
F. Prevent users from being able to use the copy and paste functions
- Could limit day to day operations

comments.content: F would block the employees to perform normal day to day business operations

discussion.content: Is this really correct? 'F' also seems like a good answer.

choices.D: Prevent users from using roaming profiles when changing workstations
choices.E: Prevent Internet access on laptops unless connected to the network in the office or via VPN
choices.A: Prevent users from accessing personal email and file-sharing sites via web proxy
choices.F: Prevent users from being able to use the copy and paste functions
choices.B: Prevent flash drives from connecting to USB ports using Group Policy
choices.C: Prevent users from copying data from workstation to workstation
